{"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2021,10,19]],"date-time":"2021-10-19T08:27:56Z","timestamp":1634632076295},"reference-count":65,"publisher":"Emerald","issue":"3","license":[{"start":{"date-parts":[[2017,8,7]],"date-time":"2017-08-07T00:00:00Z","timestamp":1502064000000},"content-version":"tdm","delay-in-days":0,"URL":"https:\/\/www.emerald.com\/insight\/site-policies"}],"content-domain":{"domain":[],"crossmark-restriction":false},"published-print":{"date-parts":[[2017,8,7]]},"abstract":"\nPurpose<\/jats:title>\nAddressing the question, how might socio-technical systems help homeless young people to succeed broadly in employment, the purpose of this paper is to present a future vision, the U-District Job Co-op, where youth take on \u201cmini-jobs\u201d offered by neighborhood stakeholders.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nDesign\/methodology\/approach<\/jats:title>\nDrawing on value sensitive design, design-based, and qualitative research methods, the Job Co-op is explicated by reporting on three linked studies.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nFindings<\/jats:title>\nFirst, based on empirical research with varied neighborhood stakeholders, barriers and possible solutions to employment for homeless young people are presented. Second, three design insights for shaping a solution space of socio-technical systems for job search are presented and used analytically to examine six existing systems. Third, findings from a co-design study in which homeless young people expressed their understandings for web-based job services explicate the vision of the Job Co-op.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nSocial implications<\/jats:title>\nThis study offers a socio-technical approach, grounded in the neighborhood context, for supporting homeless young people in job search and related activities.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nOriginality\/value<\/jats:title>\nThe studies reported in this paper demonstrate how methods for information system design can be used to generate and clarify opportunities for human benefit and for the development of socio-technical systems that account for human values.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>","DOI":"10.1108\/itp-05-2015-0117","type":"journal-article","created":{"date-parts":[[2017,6,23]],"date-time":"2017-06-23T10:56:13Z","timestamp":1498215373000},"page":"602-628","source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":12,"title":"U-District Job Co-op: constructing a future vision for homeless young people and employment","prefix":"10.1108","volume":"30","author":[{"given":"David G.","family":"Hendry","sequence":"first","affiliation":[]},{"given":"Jill Palzkill","family":"Woelfer","sequence":"additional","affiliation":[]},{"given":"Thuy","family":"Duong","sequence":"additional","affiliation":[]}],"member":"140","reference":[{"issue":"1","key":"key2020120608115397200_ref001","doi-asserted-by":"crossref","first-page":"25","DOI":"10.1257\/jep.15.1.25","article-title":"Wiring the labor market","volume":"15","year":"2001","journal-title":"Journal of Economic Perspectives"},{"issue":"3","key":"key2020120608115397200_ref002","first-page":"96","article-title":"Do temporary-help jobs improve labor market outcomes for low-skilled workers?
